_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: Facility specific training and auditing program
_prev_prog_2.Description: ANSI Standards 1989 Edition; To include customer training.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Benson Farm Service, Lewiston, MN, Winona County

Executive Summary - Ammonia Anhydrous

THE ACCIDENT RELEASE  PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE & CONTINGENCY POLICIES FOR OUR FACILITY.

The facility complies with the 1989 ANSI K61.1 "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia."  In addition, it is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws.

One of our company goals states, "To provide for the safety and security of our employees, our customers, the general public and to be good stuarts of the enviroment for which we serve."  To fulfill these goals, we enroll in regulatory management service that assist in maintaining and administer comprehensive safety and enviromental programs,  procedures and training courses.  We preform a through annual audit program and monitor facility compliance with the safety standards and overseen assistance with this specific firm.  The program consists of internal audit utilizing checklists survey forms that are reviewed regularly and updated as necessary to ensure all applicable federal, state, and local regulations are covered.  These checklists are used to measure regulatory compliance including those governing the safe handling and storage of anhydrous ammonia.  Procedures require timely response and correction of all recommendations resulting from these audit check lists.

A 'Site Saefty Coordinator' is identified and used as an extention of the general manager and management service personnel for a "hands on" manager of the day to day safe working activities, maintain the required regulatory recordkeeping, conduct monthly safety meetings, conduct employee training and act as a location contact during emergency incidents that are rehearsed biannually.

A DESCRIPTION OF THE FACILITY AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED.

The facility is a wholesale farm supply and distribution centerand as such we store and distribute a wide variety of pesticides and fertilizers including anhrdr

ous ammonia.  Anhrdrous ammonia is received by truck is handled and stored on site and is a regulated substance by EPA requiringus to comply with the risk management program.  We sell anhydrous ammonia to growers and nurse tanks manufactured to the requirements to do such.  The customer applies the ammonia into the soil as a needed source of nitrogen fertilizer for growing agricultural crops.  Ammonia is also used for blending into mixed grade liquid fertilizers for crop production nutrients.

Our facility maintains 29 - 1000 gallon nurse tanks and 4 - 1500 gallon nurse tanks for customer delivery.  Our combined storage capacity in nurse tanks is 35,000 gallons.  Anhydrous ammonia is stored in one stationary storage tank (1@26,000 gallons) on site.  121160 pounds of anhydrous ammonia is the maximum capicity of stationary storage tank.  Therefore, the total facility of anhydrous ammonia storage capacity for this location is 284,260 pounds.  The largest storage vessel at our facility contains 121,160 pounds.

WORST CASE SCENARIO

Our worst case scenario is the loss of the total contents of the 26,000 gallon storage tank, when filled to the greatest amount allowed (85% of capacity), released as a liquid over 10 minutes, resulting in total vaporization.  The maximum quantity released would be 121,160 pounds.  According to DEGRADIS modeling, the distance to the endpoint (point of dispersion to 200 ppm) would have off site impact.  It should be noted that our company has never had a total release of an entire storage tank.

ALTERNATE RELEASE SCENARIO

The most common alternate release scenario for an anhydrous ammonia storage facility would not reach an endpoint off site.  The alternate release scenario modeled for the purpose of this plan is a two-minute release from the stationary storage tank representing a valve and hose failure requiring a manual shutdown.  The total amount of anhydrous ammonia released in this scenario would be 300 pounds for a storage tank.  The di

stance to the endpoint would have an impact.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The ammonia storage system is designed, installed and is maintained in accordance with ASTM standards and the ASME codes.  This facility complies with the ANSI case 61.1 standards (1989 edition), OSHA - 29 CFR 1910.111, EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule as well as all applicable federal, state, and local codes and regulations.

Our ammonia system is protected from major releases by internal excess flow valves, check valves, relief valves, manual shutoffs, and emergency shutoff valves.  The load-out risers used for the purpose to fill the nurse tanks are protected by excess flow valves and fill lines breakaways to immediately stop the flow of anhydrous ammonia if a line or hose would fail.  All of the main storage tank valves and the riser load valves are locked when not in use.  Lighting for the facility has increased to discourage the increase of meth theft.

Our anhrdrous ammonia system is inspected on a regular basis with maintenance and preventive maintenance scheduled and documented.  Liquid and vapor valves, hoses, excess flow valves, guages, and relief valves are repleaced when necessary and according to the guidelines with the ANSI standards.

Training is provided to all employees atleast annually, whenever there is a change in the process or whenever competency with the regulations are questioned.  In accordance with the 1989 ANSI standards, training is also offered for all ammonia customers to attend on a regular basis and offered to the local fire department personnel during their annual tour of our facility and operation.  These training courses consist of classroom lecture, current and approved videos or compact disc, testing both verbally and written, demonstrations and observations for each person working with the process that are certified while on-going job training is always improved on.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HIST

ORY

There has been no accidents involving anhydrous ammonia that has caused death, recordable injuries, property or enviromental damage including evacuations on or off site.

THE 'EMERGENCY RESPONSE AND CONTIGENCY PLAN'

In the event of an emergency involving our ammonia system, it is our policy to notify the local community fire department and request that they respond to the emergency with the facilities personel assistant.  In preparation for this, we have coordinated with all the local response agencies by providing information and facility tours annually to ensure that they are familiar with and properly prepared for an incident at our facility.  This will help to ensure that our community has the stragety for responding to and mitigating the threat posed by ammonia release.  This complies the requirement of our facility to be encluded in the community emergency response plan prepared under EPCRA and coordinated with our LEPC.
